channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: The Spinoff Prize 2024
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02156-4

Nature introduces the finalists and those that made it on to the longlist for this year’s award.
item.dc:title: The Spinoff Prize 2024
item.dc:creator: Herb Brody

item.title: Blowout! Satellites reveal one of the largest methane leaks on record
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02267-y

An oil well in Kazakhstan dumped more than 100,000 tonnes of the potent greenhouse gas into the atmosphere.
item.dc:title: Blowout! Satellites reveal one of the largest methane leaks on record

item.title: Most accurate clock in history made by ‘quieting’ atoms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02199-7

Strontium-based timepiece gains or loses only one second every 40 billion years.
item.dc:title: Most accurate clock in history made by ‘quieting’ atoms

item.title: Wine grapes’ sweetness reveals Europe’s climate history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02200-3

Records on the quality of the grape harvest sheds light on 600 years of weather.
item.dc:title: Wine grapes’ sweetness reveals Europe’s climate history

item.title: De novo variants in the RNU4-2 snRNA cause a frequent neurodevelopmental syndrome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07773-7

De novo variants in the RNU4-2 snRNA cause a frequent neurodevelopmental syndrome
item.dc:title: De novo variants in the RNU4-2 snRNA cause a frequent neurodevelopmental syndrome

item.title: A Trojan horse for thirsty tumours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02163-5

Joining a drug candidate to a protein that malignant cells naturally take up allowed one firm to come up with a potent anti-cancer therapy.
item.dc:title: A Trojan horse for thirsty tumours
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: First fossil chromosomes discovered in freeze-dried mammoth skin
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02253-4

The 3D arrangement of the DNA in the animal’s cells hints at which genes were active.
item.dc:title: First fossil chromosomes discovered in freeze-dried mammoth skin
item.dc:creator: Giorgia Guglielmi

item.title: High-resolution atlas of the developing, adult and diseased human brain vasculature
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02284-x

The brain vasculature is important for the developing and mature human brain, and it plays crucial parts in several brain pathologies. Single-cell RNA sequencing enabled the construction of a single-cell atlas of the fetal, adult healthy and adult diseased human brain vasculature, uncovering its molecular architecture and heterogeneity, and capturing reactivated fetal programs as well as conserved properties in the diseased vascular endothelium.
item.dc:title: High-resolution atlas of the developing, adult and diseased human brain vasculature

item.title: A light-touch approach to intracellular delivery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02167-1

Getting molecules into cells using viral vectors or electroporation is expensive and laborious. The winner of the Spinoff Prize 2024 is showing that laser-heated nanoparticles could be an alternative solution.
item.dc:title: A light-touch approach to intracellular delivery
item.dc:creator: Tim Vernimmen

item.title: Contenders for The Spinoff Prize 2024
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02174-2

Although not chosen to be finalists, these seven science-based university spin-off companies offer potentially high-impact innovations.
item.dc:title: Contenders for The Spinoff Prize 2024
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: Infrared spectrometry guides cancer treatment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02158-2

Determining who needs chemotherapy can be an expensive and complex task. A new technology could make the process more accessible.
item.dc:title: Infrared spectrometry guides cancer treatment
item.dc:creator: Claire Ainsworth

item.title: Saliva-based tests offer an alternative to nasal swabbing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02165-3

Drooling into a tube is not only more comfortable than nasal testing, it could also detect disease earlier.
item.dc:title: Saliva-based tests offer an alternative to nasal swabbing
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: These period pads solidify blood to prevent leaks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02236-5

They’re filled with a seaweed-derived product that forms a gel and is biodegradable.
item.dc:title: These period pads solidify blood to prevent leaks
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: How the watermelon got its sweet taste and rosy hue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02265-0

Genomic analysis reveals the complex roots of the modern fruit.
item.dc:title: How the watermelon got its sweet taste and rosy hue

item.title: Breastfeeding should break down mothers’ bones — here’s why it doesn’t
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02286-9

A hormone discovered in mice could help keep bones healthy during lactation, and a new way to edit genes in the gut microbiome.
item.dc:title: Breastfeeding should break down mothers’ bones — here’s why it doesn’t
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: How anti-obesity drugs cause nausea: finding offers hope for better drugs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02254-3

The neurons that produce a sick feeling and food aversion are distinct from those that induce a feeling of fullness.
item.dc:title: How anti-obesity drugs cause nausea: finding offers hope for better drugs
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Scientists edit the genes of gut bacteria in living mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02238-3

A ‘base editor’ successfully modified a gene in more than 90% of Escherichia coli bacteria without unwanted side effects.
item.dc:title: Scientists edit the genes of gut bacteria in living mice
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Massive cicada emergence prompted raccoons to run wild
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02264-1

Meanwhile, deer kept a low profile — perhaps because the deafening noise of the insects made it hard to hear predators.
item.dc:title: Massive cicada emergence prompted raccoons to run wild

item.title: The quantum transition of the two-dimensional Ising spin glass
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07647-y

We find that, in the quantum transition of Ising spin glass, the closing of the gap at the critical point can remain algebraic by restricting the symmetry of possible excitations, which is crucial for quantum annealing.
item.dc:title: The quantum transition of the two-dimensional Ising spin glass
item.dc:creator: Massimo Bernaschi
Isidoro González-Adalid Pemartín
Víctor Martín-Mayor
Giorgio Parisi

item.title: A liver immune rheostat regulates CD8 T cell immunity in chronic HBV infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07630-7

A liver-intrinsic mechanism is presented that suppresses effective anti-hepatitis virus B responses in mice and humans by rendering virus-specific CD8 T cells refractory to activation causing loss of effector functions.
item.dc:title: A liver immune rheostat regulates CD8 T cell immunity in chronic HBV infection

item.title: CryoET of β-amyloid and tau within postmortem Alzheimer’s disease brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07680-x

The in-tissue architectures of β-amyloid and tau pathology in a postmortem Alzheimer’s disease donor brain are determined, showing fibril heterogeneity is spatially organized by subcellular location and suggesting applications to a broad range of neurodegenerative diseases.
item.dc:title: CryoET of β-amyloid and tau within postmortem Alzheimer’s disease brain
item.dc:creator: Madeleine A. G. Gilbert
Nayab Fatima
Joshua Jenkins

René A. W. Frank

item.title: Dissociable hindbrain GLP1R circuits for satiety and aversion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07685-6

The neural circuits in the hindbrain that link satiety and aversion are shown to be separate, raising the possibility of developing obesity drugs without the common side effects of nausea and vomiting.
item.dc:title: Dissociable hindbrain GLP1R circuits for satiety and aversion
item.dc:creator: Kuei-Pin Huang
Alisha A. Acosta
Misgana Y. Ghidewon
Aaron D. McKnight

item.title: Plasticity in single-crystalline Mg<sub>3</sub>Bi<sub>2</sub> thermoelectric material
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07621-8

The thermoelectric material Mg3Bi2 is shown to be ductile in single-crystal form along certain directions, with a room-temperature tensile strain of 100%, which is attributed to the gliding of dislocations.
item.dc:title: Plasticity in single-crystalline Mg<sub>3</sub>Bi<sub>2</sub> thermoelectric material

item.title: Plasmacytoid dendritic cells control homeostasis of megakaryopoiesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07671-y

Plasmacytoid dendritic cells monitor the bone marrow for apoptotic megakaryocytes (MKs) and deliver IFNα to the MK niche, triggering local on-demand proliferation and maturation of MK progenitors.
item.dc:title: Plasmacytoid dendritic cells control homeostasis of megakaryopoiesis

item.title: Brainstem Dbh+ neurons control allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07608-5

Mapping a full allergen circuit from the lung to the brainstem and back, repeated exposure of mice to inhaled allergen activated the nuclei of solitary tract neurons in a mast cell-, interleukin-4- and vagal nerve-dependent manner.
item.dc:title: Brainstem Dbh+ neurons control allergen-induced airway hyperreactivity
item.dc:creator: Yujuan Su

item.title: Interferon subverts an AHR–JUN axis to promote CXCL13<sup>+</sup> T cells in lupus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07627-2

Insufficient AHR activation has been suggested in SLE, and augmenting AHR activation therapeutically may prevent CXCL13+ TPH/TFH differentiation and the subsequent recruitment of B cells and formation of lymphoid aggregates in inflamed tissues.
item.dc:title: Interferon subverts an AHR–JUN axis to promote CXCL13<sup>+</sup> T cells in lupus

item.title: Deeper and stronger North Atlantic Gyre during the Last Glacial Maximum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07655-y

Analysis of benthic foraminiferal δ18O profiles from sediment cores in two depth transects in the Northwest Atlantic suggests that the subtropical gyre was deeper and stronger during the Last Glacial Maximum compared with today.
item.dc:title: Deeper and stronger North Atlantic Gyre during the Last Glacial Maximum
item.dc:creator: Jack H. Wharton
Martin Renoult
Geoffrey Gebbie
Lloyd D. Keigwin
Thomas M. Marchitto
Mark A. Maslin
Delia W. Oppo
David J. R. Thornalley

item.title: Fast-moving stars around an intermediate-mass black hole in ω Centauri
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07511-z

Observations of seven fast-moving stars in the central 3 arcsec (0.08  pc) of ω Centauri indicate an intermediate-mass black hole in ω Centauri.
item.dc:title: Fast-moving stars around an intermediate-mass black hole in ω Centauri
item.dc:creator: Maximilian Häberle

item.title: Cellular adaptation to cancer therapy along a resistance continuum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07690-9

Tumour cells adapt to anticancer drug treatments by a series of cellular state transitions, each inducing distinct gene expression programmes and leading to increased drug resistance.
item.dc:title: Cellular adaptation to cancer therapy along a resistance continuum
item.dc:creator: Gustavo S. França

item.title: Tumour vasculature at single-cell resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07698-1

An atlas of tumour vasculature shows that tumour angiogenesis is initiated from venous endothelial cells and extended towards arterial endothelial cells.
item.dc:title: Tumour vasculature at single-cell resolution

item.title: A maternal brain hormone that builds bone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07634-3

A brain-derived hormone, CCN3, is newly identified to have a role as an osteoanabolic factor to build bone in lactating females and in the viability of offspring.
item.dc:title: A maternal brain hormone that builds bone

item.title: In situ targeted base editing of bacteria in the mouse gut
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07681-w

Edited bacteria were stably maintained in mouse gut for at least 42 days following the delivery of a base editor using an engineered phage-derived particle to modify Escherichia coli colonizing the gut.
item.dc:title: In situ targeted base editing of bacteria in the mouse gut
item.dc:creator: Andreas K. Brödel
Loïc H. Charpenay
Matthieu Galtier

David Bikard

item.title: An enterococcal phage-derived enzyme suppresses graft-versus-host disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07667-8

An analysis of the intestinal microbiome of people who have undergone allogenic haematopoietic cell transplantation shows that an enzyme derived from a bacteriophage has specific antibacterial activity against Enterococcus faecalis, and suppresses E. faecalis-associated graft-versus-host disease.
item.dc:title: An enterococcal phage-derived enzyme suppresses graft-versus-host disease
item.dc:creator: Kosuke Fujimoto
Tetsuya Hayashi

item.title: Alveolar fibroblast lineage orchestrates lung inflammation and fibrosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07660-1

In mouse and human, lung-specialized alveolar fibroblasts adopt multiple molecular states that are induced by pro-inflammatory and fibrotic signals and have diverse protective roles against lung injury.
item.dc:title: Alveolar fibroblast lineage orchestrates lung inflammation and fibrosis
item.dc:creator: Tatsuya Tsukui
Paul J. Wolters
Dean Sheppard

item.title: Antiferromagnetic phase transition in a 3D fermionic Hubbard model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07689-2

Antiferromagnetic phase transition is observed in a three-dimensional fermionic Hubbard system comprising lithium-6 atoms in a uniform optical lattice with approximately 800,000 sites.
item.dc:title: Antiferromagnetic phase transition in a 3D fermionic Hubbard model
item.dc:creator: Hou-Ji Shao
Yu-Xuan Wang
De-Zhi Zhu
Yan-Song Zhu
Hao-Nan Sun

Zhi-Jie Fan

Jian-Wei Pan

item.title: Phage anti-CRISPR control by an RNA- and DNA-binding helix–turn–helix protein
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07644-1

The helix–turn–helix domain of an anti-CRISPR-associated (Aca) protein represses transcription of anti-CRISPR (Acr)-encoding genes and inhibits their translation to protein via distinct binding modes to DNA and RNA, respectively.
item.dc:title: Phage anti-CRISPR control by an RNA- and DNA-binding helix–turn–helix protein
item.dc:creator: Nils Birkholz

Peter C. Fineran

item.title: Airborne DNA reveals predictable spatial and seasonal dynamics of fungi
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07658-9

Using a globally distributed standardized aerial sampling of fungal spores, we show that the hyperdiverse kingdom of fungi follows globally highly predictable spatial and temporal dynamics, with seasonality in both species richness and community composition increasing with latitude.
item.dc:title: Airborne DNA reveals predictable spatial and seasonal dynamics of fungi

item.title: Single-cell atlas of the human brain vasculature across development, adulthood and disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07493-y

Endothelial cells from vascular-dependent central nervous system (CNS) diseases reveal reactivated fetal pathways, display common hallmarks of disease — including a partial loss of arteriovenous specification and CNS-specific properties as well as an upregulation of MHC class II receptors — and play a key role in the human brain neurovascular unit across development, adulthood and disease.
item.dc:title: Single-cell atlas of the human brain vasculature across development, adulthood and disease

item.title: Repeated plague infections across six generations of Neolithic Farmers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07651-2

Population-scale ancient genomics are used to infer ancestry, social structure and pathogen infection in 108 Scandinavian Neolithic individuals from eight megalithic graves and a stone cist, showing that Neolithic plague was widespread.
item.dc:title: Repeated plague infections across six generations of Neolithic Farmers

item.title: Glutamate acts on acid-sensing ion channels to worsen ischaemic brain injury
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07684-7

Glutamate functions as a positive allosteric modulator for acid-sensing ion channels to exacerbate ischaemic neurotoxicity.
item.dc:title: Glutamate acts on acid-sensing ion channels to worsen ischaemic brain injury
item.dc:creator: Ke Lai

item.title: Magnetic field expulsion in optically driven YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6.48</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07635-2

A time-dependent magnetic field expulsion was measured in optically driven YBa2Cu3O6.48 above the equilibrium superconducting transition temperature and all the way to room temperature.
item.dc:title: Magnetic field expulsion in optically driven YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6.48</sub>
item.dc:creator: S. Fava
G. De Vecchi
G. Jotzu
M. Buzzi
T. Gebert
Y. Liu
B. Keimer
A. Cavalleri

item.title: Emergence of large-scale cell death through ferroptotic trigger waves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07623-6

Ferroptosis can propagate across human cells over long distances (≥5 mm) at constant speeds (around 5.5 μm per minute) through self-regenerating waves of reactive oxygen species; such waves facilitate large-scale cell death in the developing avian limb.
item.dc:title: Emergence of large-scale cell death through ferroptotic trigger waves
item.dc:creator: Hannah K. C. Co
Chia-Chou Wu
Yi-Chen Lee
Sheng-hong Chen

item.title: Waves of ferroptotic cell death sculpt embryonic tissue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02125-x

An unusual form of cell death called ferroptosis can sweep over embryonic tissues in a wave-like manner to ensure proper muscle development — evidence that ferroptosis has a role in normal physiology.
item.dc:title: Waves of ferroptotic cell death sculpt embryonic tissue
item.dc:creator: Judith Goncalves
Scott J. Dixon

item.title: Some photos you might like
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02189-9

A life, tagged.
item.dc:title: Some photos you might like
item.dc:creator: Bob McHugh

item.title: Multiple plague outbreaks in a Neolithic family give clues to prehistoric population dip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02243-6

A reconstruction of the occurrence of plague in a large family tree from Neolithic Sweden indicates that 12 of 38 family members were infected in three separate waves — a potential explanation for a mysterious collapse in northern Europe’s population five millennia ago.
item.dc:title: Multiple plague outbreaks in a Neolithic family give clues to prehistoric population dip

item.title: Speedy stars blow the cover of hidden black hole
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02135-9

Fast-moving stars have been discovered in the middle of the nearby star cluster ω Centauri using two decades of Hubble Space Telescope imaging. The stars offer evidence of a long-sought intermediate-mass black hole.
item.dc:title: Speedy stars blow the cover of hidden black hole
item.dc:creator: Daryl Haggard
Adrienne Cool

item.title: Stars hint at an unusual black hole lurking in our Galaxy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02277-w

Images taken by the Hubble Space Telescope point to an elusive intermediate-size black hole in the star cluster ω Centauri.
item.dc:title: Stars hint at an unusual black hole lurking in our Galaxy
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Alzheimer’s plaques and tangles revealed by 3D microscopy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02119-9

Amyloid-β peptides and tau proteins form filaments in the brain in Alzheimer’s disease. Using an electron microscopy approach to visualize thin slices of brain tissue in 3D, these filaments can be seen in their native environment.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s plaques and tangles revealed by 3D microscopy
item.dc:creator: Sjors H. W. Scheres

item.title: This lab-grown meat probably tastes like real beef
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02273-0

Cultured meat that tastes and smells more appetizing could enhance public perception of artificial steaks.
item.dc:title: This lab-grown meat probably tastes like real beef
item.dc:creator: Helena Kudiabor

item.title: Serious errors plague DNA tool that’s a workhorse of biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02280-1

Researchers analysed thousands of laboratory-made plasmids and discovered that nearly half of them had defects, raising questions of experimental reproducibility.
item.dc:title: Serious errors plague DNA tool that’s a workhorse of biology
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: Edward C. Stone obituary: physicist who guided Voyager probes to interstellar space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02285-w

Space scientist who took humanity on a tour of the Solar System and beyond, in a journey of discovery like no other.
item.dc:title: Edward C. Stone obituary: physicist who guided Voyager probes to interstellar space
item.dc:creator: Alan C. Cummings

item.title: Publisher Correction: Titanium:sapphire-on-insulator integrated lasers and amplifiers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07775-5

Publisher Correction: Titanium:sapphire-on-insulator integrated lasers and amplifiers
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Titanium:sapphire-on-insulator integrated lasers and amplifiers

item.title: Author Correction: Obesity induces PD-1 on macrophages to suppress anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07794-2

Author Correction: Obesity induces PD-1 on macrophages to suppress anti-tumour immunity
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Obesity induces PD-1 on macrophages to suppress anti-tumour immunity

item.title: How mud brought France and England together — 150 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02229-4

Artificial daylight lacks commercial interest, and a geologist’s thirst for knowledge kickstarts the bid for the Channel Tunnel, in our weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: How mud brought France and England together — 150 years ago

item.title: To explain biological sex, look to evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02248-1

To explain biological sex, look to evolution
item.dc:title: To explain biological sex, look to evolution
item.dc:creator: Paul E. Griffiths
Hamish G. Spencer

item.title: Regulate to protect fragile Antarctic ecosystems from growing tourism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02250-7

Regulate to protect fragile Antarctic ecosystems from growing tourism
item.dc:title: Regulate to protect fragile Antarctic ecosystems from growing tourism
item.dc:creator: Yi Luo
Huan Zhong
Chengjun Li
Christian Sonne

item.title: Storm-chasing seabirds served supper by cyclones
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02201-2

The ocean-going Desertas petrel often follows storms for days over thousands of kilometres.
item.dc:title: Storm-chasing seabirds served supper by cyclones

item.title: More studies needed on how climate change affects exercise health benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02249-0

More studies needed on how climate change affects exercise health benefits
item.dc:title: More studies needed on how climate change affects exercise health benefits
item.dc:creator: Zhenxiang Guo

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: How to beat ‘superhuman’ AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02283-y

A Go-playing algorithm that can beat the world’s best human players can be defeated by adversarial bots. Plus, a protein chatbot that designs ‘biotechnology workhorse’ molecules from scratch and how attention lets mind-reading AI see better.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: How to beat ‘superhuman’ AI
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Vaccines save lives: how can uptake be increased?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02224-9

Strategies for public engagement need to be rigorously tested around the world to maximize the potential of immunization.
item.dc:title: Vaccines save lives: how can uptake be increased?

item.title: Iran elects heart surgeon as president: scientists are hopeful
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02262-3

Researchers say unexpected victory for Masoud Pezeshkian could spell improvements to human rights, investment in science and academic freedom — if Iran’s top leaders give him space to act.
item.dc:title: Iran elects heart surgeon as president: scientists are hopeful
item.dc:creator: Michele Catanzaro

item.title: If bird flu sparks a human pandemic, your past immunity could help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02170-6

Older populations might be more protected than younger ones because of exposure to ‘matched’ strains during childhood, but an H5N1 pandemic is likely to take a major toll all the same.
item.dc:title: If bird flu sparks a human pandemic, your past immunity could help
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Canada just hiked PhD and postdoc pay — here’s how to get your country to do it, too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02227-6

Walkouts, petitions and tweets: how a grass-roots movement led by students, postdocs and tenured academics radically changed government policy on science funding.
item.dc:title: Canada just hiked PhD and postdoc pay — here’s how to get your country to do it, too
item.dc:creator: Kaitlin Kharas

item.title: How PhD students and other academics are fighting the mental-health crisis in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02225-8

Universities and institutions across the globe are exploring unique initiatives to help their students and staff cope with the stress of research.
item.dc:title: How PhD students and other academics are fighting the mental-health crisis in science
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: Chiral perovskites deliver spin control to a conventional semiconductor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02263-2

The integration of a chiral halide perovskite semiconductor into a light-emitting diode (LED) structure made from a III–V optoelectronic semiconductor creates a spin-LED that achieves 15% circularly polarized emission at room temperature without a magnetic field — a potential boon for spintronics and other spin‑based technologies.
item.dc:title: Chiral perovskites deliver spin control to a conventional semiconductor

item.title: Ultracold molecules that interact from afar form elusive quantum state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02134-w

A gas of molecules that interact over long distances has been cooled to mere nanokelvins, resulting in the emergence of a state known as a Bose–Einstein condensate — the first of its kind in this type of molecular system.
item.dc:title: Ultracold molecules that interact from afar form elusive quantum state
item.dc:creator: Lauriane Chomaz

item.title: Huge neutrino detector sees first hints of particles from exploding stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02221-y

Japan’s Super-Kamiokande observatory could be seeing evidence of neutrinos from supernovae across cosmic history.
item.dc:title: Huge neutrino detector sees first hints of particles from exploding stars
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Daily briefing: Zircons rewrite history of plate tectonics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02278-9

Unbelievably ancient crystals suggest plate tectonics started earlier than we thought. Plus, the little-known anti-science movement that spawned a thousand conspiracies and why faecal transplants are only a ‘stepping stone’ towards better cancer treatments.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Zircons rewrite history of plate tectonics
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Hydrogen sulfide and metal-enriched atmosphere for a Jupiter-mass exoplanet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07760-y

Hydrogen sulfide and metal-enriched atmosphere for a Jupiter-mass exoplanet
item.dc:title: Hydrogen sulfide and metal-enriched atmosphere for a Jupiter-mass exoplanet

item.title: Why I work to revive the Tasmanian tiger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02228-5

Andrew Pask develops genetic sequencing techniques for marsupials — including an apex predator that was hunted to death in the twentieth century.
item.dc:title: Why I work to revive the Tasmanian tiger
item.dc:creator: Margaret Simons
